powers: 3,000-year: basic immortality; 6,000-year: enhanced powers; 9,000-year: cosmic immortality

textReferences.context: Sun Wukong steals and consumes the peaches of immortality
Describes Xi Wangmu's garden and the immortal peaches
Xi Wangmu visits Emperor Wu and presents him with peaches of immortality

associatedDeities.name: Xi Wangmu (Queen Mother of the West)

mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: The peach is one of China's most auspicious symbols, representing longevity, vitality, and divine favor. Peach imagery appears in art, literature, birthday celebrations (especially for elders), and festivals. The peach blossom is also a symbol of spring renewal and romantic love.
mythologyContexts.usage: Consumed by celestial deities and worthy mortals to achieve immortality. Featured prominently in the Peach Banquet of the Jade Emperor and stolen by Sun Wukong during his rebellion against heaven
mythologyContexts.symbolism: The Peaches of Immortality symbolize the ultimate spiritual achievement - transcendence of death and entry into the celestial realm. Their extreme rarity (ripening only once every millennia) represents the difficulty of attaining true immortality and enlightenment. The three tiers of peaches reflect different levels of spiritual cultivation, from basic longevity to cosmic consciousness.

rituals.description: Every 3,000 years, the Jade Emperor hosts a grand banquet where celestial beings feast on the peaches of immortality
rituals.name: Peach Banquet of Heaven
Sun Wukong's Theft
rituals.description: The Monkey King, excluded from the banquet, infiltrated Xi Wangmu's garden and consumed vast quantities of peaches, adding to his already formidable immortality
Xi Wangmu occasionally grants peaches to worthy mortals, such as Emperor Wu of Han, as a mark of divine favor
rituals.name: Gift of Immortality

temporal.philosophicalContext: Daoist immortality symbolism; Xi Wangmu's celestial banquets; connection to longevity and divine favor

firstAttestation.description: Han Wu Di Nei Zhuan describes Xi Wangmu's peaches; fully developed in Journey to the West (1592)

longDescription: The Peaches of Immortality (Ëü†Ê°É, p√°nt√°o) are celestial fruits that grow in the sacred garden of Xi Wangmu, the Queen Mother of the West, on Mount Kunlun. These divine peaches ripen only once every 3,000, 6,000, or 9,000 years depending on the tree, with the oldest granting the highest levels of immortality and cosmic power. Consuming these peaches grants eternal life, supernatural abilities, and transformation into a xian (immortal). The Jade Emperor hosts the legendary Peach Banquet every 3,000 years where celestial beings feast on these fruits.

originPoint.description: Divine peaches grow in Xi Wangmu's garden on Kunlun Mountain; ripen once every 3,000 or 9,000 years

name: Peach of Immortality

worshipPractices: Consumed by celestial deities and worthy mortals to achieve immortality. Featured prominently in the Peach Banquet of the Jade Emperor and stolen by Sun Wukong during his rebellion against heaven

modernLegacy.culturalImpact: The peach is one of China's most auspicious symbols, representing longevity, vitality, and divine favor. Peach imagery appears in art, literature, birthday celebrations (especially for elders), and festivals. The peach blossom is also a symbol of spring renewal and romantic love.

festivals.name: Gift of Immortality

shortDescription: Divine fruit from Xi Wangmu's garden that grants immortality and cosmic longevity

etymology.components: Ëü† (coiled, curled) + Ê°É (peach) - referring to flat, disc-shaped divine peaches
